Table of Contents

NAME

chngolombencode - Golomb encoding of a binary channel

SYNOPSIS

chngolombencode [-s] [-vo] [-p probability] [-m m] channel bitstream

OPTIONS

-s
Silent mode (no printed output).
-vo
Print only the value of the rate to stdout (terse output).
-p probability
Probability of the favorable event (run symbol). p >= 1/2.
-m m
The m that satisfies p^m = 1/2. m >= 1.

DESCRIPTION

chngolombencode implements Golomb coding of the binary channel sequence, channel (CHN format). chngolombencode calls QccENTGolombEncodeChannel(3) , which encodes the channel symbols, and outputs codewords to the output bitstream.

chngolombencode initially outputs a few bytes of header information (original number of symbols in channel, symbol alphabet size, and m) to bitstream. The byte-packed bitstream produced by the Golomb coding follows.

Normally, chngolombencode prints to stdout the rate achieved by the Golomb coding, expressed in terms of bits per channel symbol. This output may be suppressed by the -s option (silent mode). The -vo option indicates that only the value of the rate is to be printed (terse output). The -s option overrides the -vo option.

NOTES

When neither p nor m is specified, the probability of the favorable event is estimated automatically.

chngolombencode removes all null channel symbols from the channel with a call to QccChannelRemoveNullSymbols(3) prior to Golomb coding.

Golomb coding originated in the 1966 paper by Golomb, which is classic, short, and beautifully written with a sense of humour.

SEE ALSO

chngolombdecode(1) , QccENTGolombEncodeChannel(3) , QccENTGolombDecodeChannel(3) , QccChannelRemoveNullSymbols(3) , chnentropy(1) , QccPackENT(3) , QccPack(3)

S. W. Golomb, "Run-Length Encodings," IEEE Transactions on Information Theory, vol. 12, pp. 399-401, July 1966.

AUTHOR

Written by Yufei Yuan <yuanyufei@hotmail.com>
